objinfo.framelines: 1A single framing line in pencil extends around the design.

provenance.name: Collection of Robert N. Essick
provenance.note: Probably inherited by Catherine Blake upon the death of her husband, William Blake, in 1827; possibly acquired by Frederick Tatham upon the death of Catherine Blake in 1831; possibly one of the three Last Judgment designs by Blake sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, in lot 179 with Butlin 643 and 644 (15s. to the dealer H. Palser); this work or the untraced Butlin 647 in the possession of Francis Cunningham by 1866; Anne Gilchrist (Mrs. Alexander Gilchrist) by 1880; possibly Herbert H. Gilchrist by inheritance in 1885; W. S. Brough; sold from his collection, Sotheby's, 19 April 1919, lot 15 (£4 to William Bateson); Mrs. William Bateson by inheritance in 1926; her son, Gregory Bateson; his wife, Lois Bateson, by inheritance in 1980; sold from L. Bateson's collection, Sotheby's, 15 Nov. 1990, lot 26 (£4180 to the dealer Donald Heald acting for Robert N. Essick).

objnote.p: This work is a tracing of Butlin 645, *The Last Judgment* in the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C. As Butlin 646 points out, the tracing "is not without life and possibly by Blake." It may be the same as the untraced drawing, Butlin 647. If indeed by Blake, he may have made this tracing as part of some unrealized intention to engrave the design.
